key_points: Derek Chauvin, a former Minneapolis Police officer, was found guilty of second-degree unintentional murder, third-degree murder, and second-degree manslaughter in the killing of George Floyd.
Chauvin was convicted after more than 10 hours of jury deliberation over two days.
Following the verdict, Chauvin's bail was revoked, and he was taken into custody.
The charges stem from Chauvin kneeling on George Floyd's neck for over 9 minutes, leading to Floyd's death.
Chauvin could face up to 40 years for second-degree murder, 25 years for third-degree murder, and 10 years for manslaughter.
The case has been highly influential, symbolizing racial injustice in the United States and prompting widespread protests.
Philonise Floyd, George Floyd's brother, expressed relief and a sense of justice following the verdict.
The trial, broadcasted live due to COVID-19 restrictions, drew national attention to the legal proceedings.
President Joe Biden commented on the verdict, expressing that it could be a step forward towards justice in America.
Minnesota Attorney General Keith Ellison emphasized that the verdict signifies accountability, which is the first step toward justice.
spokespersons: Joe Biden (President of the United States)
